Importing UK Air Quality Data

Source: vignettes/articles/ukaq.Rmd
ukaq.Rmd
library(ukaq)

Metadata

The first step when importing air quality data is to consult import_ukaq_meta(). Let‚Äôs have a look at the AURN metadata now:

import_ukaq_meta("aurn")
#> # A tibble: 316 √ó 14
#>    source code  site    site_type latitude longitude start_date end_date   zone 
#>    <chr>  <chr> <chr>   <chr>        <dbl>     <dbl> <date>     <date>     <chr>
#>  1 aurn   ABD   Aberde‚Ä¶ Urban Ba‚Ä¶     57.2    -2.09  1999-09-18 2021-09-20 Nort‚Ä¶
#>  2 aurn   ABD9  Aberde‚Ä¶ Urban Ba‚Ä¶     57.2    -2.09  2021-10-01 NA         Nort‚Ä¶
#>  3 aurn   ABD7  Aberde‚Ä¶ Urban Tr‚Ä¶     57.1    -2.11  2008-01-01 2024-12-31 Nort‚Ä¶
#>  4 aurn   ABD8  Aberde‚Ä¶ Urban Tr‚Ä¶     57.1    -2.09  2016-02-09 NA         Nort‚Ä¶
#>  5 aurn   ARM6  Armagh‚Ä¶ Urban Tr‚Ä¶     54.4    -6.65  2009-01-01 NA         Nort‚Ä¶
#>  6 aurn   AH    Aston ‚Ä¶ Rural Ba‚Ä¶     52.5    -3.03  1986-06-26 NA         Nort‚Ä¶
#>  7 aurn   ACTH  Auchen‚Ä¶ Rural Ba‚Ä¶     55.8    -3.24  2006-01-01 NA         Cent‚Ä¶
#>  8 aurn   AYLA  Aylesb‚Ä¶ Urban Tr‚Ä¶     51.8    -0.794 2025-06-19 NA         Sout‚Ä¶
#>  9 aurn   BAAR  Ballym‚Ä¶ Urban Tr‚Ä¶     54.9    -6.27  2017-04-01 NA         Nort‚Ä¶
#> 10 aurn   BALM  Ballym‚Ä¶ Urban Ba‚Ä¶     54.9    -6.25  2010-01-01 NA         Nort‚Ä¶
#> # ‚Ñπ 306 more rows
#> # ‚Ñπ 5 more variables: agglomeration <chr>, zagglom <chr>,
#> #   local_authority <chr>, lmam_provider <chr>, lmam_code <chr>

This output can be customised using different function arguments. For example, lets find sites which measured O3 in 2020.

meta <- import_ukaq_meta("aurn", year = 2020, by_pollutant = TRUE)
meta[meta$pollutant == "O3",]
#> # A tibble: 0 √ó 16
#> # ‚Ñπ 16 variables: source <chr>, code <chr>, site <chr>, site_type <chr>,
#> #   latitude <dbl>, longitude <dbl>, pollutant <chr>, start_date <date>,
#> #   end_date <date>, ratified_to <date>, zone <chr>, agglomeration <chr>,
#> #   zagglom <chr>, local_authority <chr>, lmam_provider <chr>, lmam_code <chr>

To import data, please make a note of the relevant site codes in the ‚Äúcode‚Äù column (and, if appropriate, the ‚Äúsource‚Äù network of the data).

Continuous Monitoring

Arguably the most useful data made available by ukaq could be termed ‚Äòcontinuous monitoring data‚Äô - most commonly hourly data. To access this, you may use import_ukaq_measurements() which requires two key pieces of information - a site code from the metadata table and a year (or years) to import.

import_ukaq_measurements(c("my1", "kc1"), year = 2024L)
#> # A tibble: 17,568 √ó 44
#>    source date                code  site        o3    no   no2   nox   so2    co
#>    <chr>  <dttm>              <fct> <chr>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 aurn   2024-01-01 00:00:00 MY1   London ‚Ä¶  39.7  22.1  30.4  64.3  1.33 0.244
#>  2 aurn   2024-01-01 01:00:00 MY1   London ‚Ä¶  23.7  43.0  48.4 114.   2.39 0.373
#>  3 aurn   2024-01-01 02:00:00 MY1   London ‚Ä¶  31.3  28.9  41.1  85.5  1.86 0.268
#>  4 aurn   2024-01-01 03:00:00 MY1   London ‚Ä¶  34.1  23.0  37.5  72.7  1.60 0.314
#>  5 aurn   2024-01-01 04:00:00 MY1   London ‚Ä¶  37.1  23.2  37.9  73.4  1.33 0.256
#>  6 aurn   2024-01-01 05:00:00 MY1   London ‚Ä¶  39.5  14.6  28.5  50.9  1.06 0.244
#>  7 aurn   2024-01-01 06:00:00 MY1   London ‚Ä¶  35.5  17.7  34.2  61.2  1.06 0.221
#>  8 aurn   2024-01-01 07:00:00 MY1   London ‚Ä¶  37.7  13.0  31.2  50.9  1.06 0.186
#>  9 aurn   2024-01-01 08:00:00 MY1   London ‚Ä¶  33.1  20.1  37.7  68.7  1.06 0.186
#> 10 aurn   2024-01-01 09:00:00 MY1   London ‚Ä¶  32.7  17.0  37.3  63.5  1.06 0.163
#> # ‚Ñπ 17,558 more rows
#> # ‚Ñπ 34 more variables: pm10 <dbl>, pm2.5 <dbl>, ethane <dbl>, ethene <dbl>,
#> #   ethyne <dbl>, propane <dbl>, propene <dbl>, ibutane <dbl>, nbutane <dbl>,
#> #   `1butene` <dbl>, t2butene <dbl>, c2butene <dbl>, ipentane <dbl>,
#> #   npentane <dbl>, `13bdiene` <dbl>, t2penten <dbl>, `1penten` <dbl>,
#> #   `2mepent` <dbl>, isoprene <dbl>, nhexane <dbl>, nheptane <dbl>,
#> #   ioctane <dbl>, noctane <dbl>, benzene <dbl>, toluene <dbl>, ‚Ä¶

import_ukaq_measurements() is clever enough to work out the specific monitoring network each site is a member of, but sometimes there can be ambiguity. The source argument allows this to be specified. Consider source as defining the pool of one or more networks ukaq will use to align each code with an actual monitoring station. In reality, this should only be an issue for ‚Äúlocally managed‚Äù English sites which share site codes with Ricardo-managed sites (e.g., ‚ÄúAD1‚Äù which is the ‚ÄòAberdeen King Street‚Äô AURN site and the ‚ÄòAdur - Shoreham-by-Sea‚Äô Sussex AQ site). Consider the difference between the two outputs below.

import_ukaq_measurements("ad1", year = 2020L)
#> Warning in import_ukaq_measurements("ad1", year = 2020L): Ambiguous Codes Detected: AD1.
#> Importing sites using following order of preference: aurn, aqe, saqn, waqn, niaqn, lmam
#> # A tibble: 8,784 √ó 13
#>    source date                code  site        no   no2   nox  pm10 pm2.5   pm1
#>    <chr>  <dttm>              <fct> <chr>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 saqn   2020-01-01 00:00:00 AD1   Aberdee‚Ä¶ 4.22  17.8  24.3  15.6  13.1  12.4 
#>  2 saqn   2020-01-01 01:00:00 AD1   Aberdee‚Ä¶ 6.04  19.5  28.8   7.24  5.92  5.33
#>  3 saqn   2020-01-01 02:00:00 AD1   Aberdee‚Ä¶ 5.07  21.1  28.9   9.75  8.35  7.93
#>  4 saqn   2020-01-01 03:00:00 AD1   Aberdee‚Ä¶ 1.53   9.97 12.3   5.00  3.83  3.37
#>  5 saqn   2020-01-01 04:00:00 AD1   Aberdee‚Ä¶ 1.02   9.83 11.4   5.00  3.81  3.32
#>  6 saqn   2020-01-01 05:00:00 AD1   Aberdee‚Ä¶ 0.716  5.16  6.25  3.86  2.94  2.59
#>  7 saqn   2020-01-01 06:00:00 AD1   Aberdee‚Ä¶ 0.575  5.79  6.67  4.24  3.31  2.97
#>  8 saqn   2020-01-01 07:00:00 AD1   Aberdee‚Ä¶ 1.03   7.99  9.57  3.88  3.19  2.96
#>  9 saqn   2020-01-01 08:00:00 AD1   Aberdee‚Ä¶ 8.26  23.6  36.2   4.49  3.71  3.48
#> 10 saqn   2020-01-01 09:00:00 AD1   Aberdee‚Ä¶ 6.07  26.6  35.9   6.32  5.04  4.80
#> # ‚Ñπ 8,774 more rows
#> # ‚Ñπ 3 more variables: wd <dbl>, ws <dbl>, temp <dbl>

import_ukaq_measurements("ad1", year = 2020L, source = "lmam")
#> # A tibble: 8,784 √ó 8
#>    source date                code  site                    no   no2   nox  pm10
#>    <chr>  <dttm>              <fct> <chr>                <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 lmam   2020-01-01 00:00:00 AD1   Adur - Shoreham-by-‚Ä¶ NA     NA    NA      39
#>  2 lmam   2020-01-01 01:00:00 AD1   Adur - Shoreham-by-‚Ä¶ 23.7   52.2  88.0    38
#>  3 lmam   2020-01-01 02:00:00 AD1   Adur - Shoreham-by-‚Ä¶ 12.5   45.9  65.2    36
#>  4 lmam   2020-01-01 03:00:00 AD1   Adur - Shoreham-by-‚Ä¶ 12.5   47.2  65.6    34
#>  5 lmam   2020-01-01 04:00:00 AD1   Adur - Shoreham-by-‚Ä¶ 26.2   52.4  92.2    38
#>  6 lmam   2020-01-01 05:00:00 AD1   Adur - Shoreham-by-‚Ä¶  6.24  30.8  39.8    37
#>  7 lmam   2020-01-01 06:00:00 AD1   Adur - Shoreham-by-‚Ä¶  7.48  27.9  39.6    37
#>  8 lmam   2020-01-01 07:00:00 AD1   Adur - Shoreham-by-‚Ä¶ 15.0   30.6  52.8    34
#>  9 lmam   2020-01-01 08:00:00 AD1   Adur - Shoreham-by-‚Ä¶ 15.0   30.6  52.8    38
#> 10 lmam   2020-01-01 09:00:00 AD1   Adur - Shoreham-by-‚Ä¶ 36.2   37.1  91.8    33
#> # ‚Ñπ 8,774 more rows

Data can be augmented with three kinds of extra information to make the functions more useful:

  1. append_meteorology will add modelled wind speed (ws), wind direction (wd), and air temperature (temp) for networks where it exists. This defaults to TRUE.

  2. append_quality_flag will add a column (or columns) to indicate whether each pollutant has been ratified. This defaults to FALSE.

  3. append_metadata will add the metadata columns defined in metadata_columns. This is useful to append information like latitude/longitude for mapping, for example. This defaults to FALSE, with chosen metadata being site type, latitude and longitude.

To demonstrate we‚Äôll just grab a couple of pollutants from Marylebone Road ("my1") using the pollutant argument, to keep the output small.

import_ukaq_measurements(
  "my1", 
  2020L,  
  pollutant = c("no2", "o3"),
  append_metadata = TRUE, 
  append_meteorology = FALSE, 
  append_quality_flag = TRUE, 
  metadata_columns = "zagglom"
)
#> # A tibble: 8,784 √ó 9
#>    code  source date                site          no2    o3 o3_qc no2_qc zagglom
#>    <fct> <chr>  <dttm>              <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <lgl> <lgl>  <chr>  
#>  1 MY1   aurn   2020-01-01 00:00:00 London Mar‚Ä¶  45.8  1.73 TRUE  TRUE   Greate‚Ä¶
#>  2 MY1   aurn   2020-01-01 01:00:00 London Mar‚Ä¶  52.6  1.93 TRUE  TRUE   Greate‚Ä¶
#>  3 MY1   aurn   2020-01-01 02:00:00 London Mar‚Ä¶  44.8  2.00 TRUE  TRUE   Greate‚Ä¶
#>  4 MY1   aurn   2020-01-01 03:00:00 London Mar‚Ä¶  40.2  2.05 TRUE  TRUE   Greate‚Ä¶
#>  5 MY1   aurn   2020-01-01 04:00:00 London Mar‚Ä¶  47.3  2.99 TRUE  TRUE   Greate‚Ä¶
#>  6 MY1   aurn   2020-01-01 05:00:00 London Mar‚Ä¶  40.4  2.89 TRUE  TRUE   Greate‚Ä¶
#>  7 MY1   aurn   2020-01-01 06:00:00 London Mar‚Ä¶  42.7  2.99 TRUE  TRUE   Greate‚Ä¶
#>  8 MY1   aurn   2020-01-01 07:00:00 London Mar‚Ä¶  40.7  1.90 TRUE  TRUE   Greate‚Ä¶
#>  9 MY1   aurn   2020-01-01 08:00:00 London Mar‚Ä¶  42.6  1.85 TRUE  TRUE   Greate‚Ä¶
#> 10 MY1   aurn   2020-01-01 09:00:00 London Mar‚Ä¶  38.3  1.95 TRUE  TRUE   Greate‚Ä¶
#> # ‚Ñπ 8,774 more rows

By default, the data is put into a ‚Äòwide‚Äô format, with different pollutants in different columns. For many applications in R, we may want the data to be in a ‚Äúlong‚Äù format. For this data structure, simply set pivot = "long". Note that this will interact with the other ‚Äòappend‚Äô arguments - meteorological data and site metadata aren‚Äôt pivoted with the pollutants, and there will only be a single quality flag alongside the ‚Äòvalue‚Äô column.

import_ukaq_measurements(
  "my1",
  2020L,
  pivot = "long"
)
#> # A tibble: 377,712 √ó 9
#>    source date                code  site          wd    ws  temp pollutant value
#>    <chr>  <dttm>              <fct> <chr>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>     <dbl>
#>  1 aurn   2020-01-01 00:00:00 MY1   London Ma‚Ä¶  92.7   2.1   2.3 o3         1.73
#>  2 aurn   2020-01-01 01:00:00 MY1   London Ma‚Ä¶  98.3   2.1   1.4 o3         1.93
#>  3 aurn   2020-01-01 02:00:00 MY1   London Ma‚Ä¶ 117.    2.3   1   o3         2.00
#>  4 aurn   2020-01-01 03:00:00 MY1   London Ma‚Ä¶ 131.    1.8   0.8 o3         2.05
#>  5 aurn   2020-01-01 04:00:00 MY1   London Ma‚Ä¶ 109.    1.7   0.8 o3         2.99
#>  6 aurn   2020-01-01 05:00:00 MY1   London Ma‚Ä¶  84.3   1.1   0   o3         2.89
#>  7 aurn   2020-01-01 06:00:00 MY1   London Ma‚Ä¶  86.9   1.2  -0.4 o3         2.99
#>  8 aurn   2020-01-01 07:00:00 MY1   London Ma‚Ä¶ 143     1.3   0.9 o3         1.90
#>  9 aurn   2020-01-01 08:00:00 MY1   London Ma‚Ä¶ 168.    1.1   1.5 o3         1.85
#> 10 aurn   2020-01-01 09:00:00 MY1   London Ma‚Ä¶ 186.    0.6   1.5 o3         1.95
#> # ‚Ñπ 377,702 more rows

Finally, there are other data types available if they are of interest, which can be used with the data_type argument of import_ukaq_measurements(). These include:

  • "hourly": Hourly data (the default).

  • "daily": Daily average data.

  • "15_min": 15-minute average SO2 concentrations.

  • "8_hour": 8-hour rolling mean concentrations for O3 and CO.

  • "24_hour": 24-hour rolling mean concentrations for particulates.

  • "daily_max_8": Maximum daily rolling 8-hour maximum for O3 and CO.

On top of these data types, there are three additional data_types that can be accessed through other functions, detailed in the sections below.

Monthly & Annual Statistics

When examining entire networks, it may be useful to examine aggregated data. import_ukaq_summaries() allows for "monthly" and "annual" data types to be imported. This function works differently to import_ukaq_measurements() in a few key ways.

  1. A pre-calculated monthly or annual data capture is also returned with the data.

  2. code is optional (defaulting to NULL) which will make the function return all data available for the given source and year.

Many of the arguments mentioned in the above section are also available for this function, including pollutant, append_metadata, metadata_columns, and pivot.

import_ukaq_summaries(year = 2024, source = "aurn")
#> # A tibble: 187 √ó 89
#>    source date        year code  site            o3 o3.capture o3.summer.capture
#>    <chr>  <date>     <int> <chr> <chr>        <dbl>      <dbl>             <dbl>
#>  1 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 ABD7  Aberdeen Un‚Ä¶  NA       NA               NA     
#>  2 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 ABD8  Aberdeen We‚Ä¶  NA       NA               NA     
#>  3 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 ABD9  Aberdeen Er‚Ä¶  56.0      0.878            0.959 
#>  4 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 ACTH  Auchencorth‚Ä¶  59.2      0.998            0.999 
#>  5 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 AH    Aston Hill    63.4      0.991            0.991 
#>  6 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 ARM6  Armagh Road‚Ä¶  NA       NA               NA     
#>  7 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 BAAR  Ballymena A‚Ä¶  NA       NA               NA     
#>  8 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 BALM  Ballymena B‚Ä¶  NA       NA               NA     
#>  9 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 BAR3  Barnsley Ga‚Ä¶  56.9      0.292            0.0947
#> 10 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 BBRD  Birkenhead ‚Ä¶  NA       NA               NA     
#> # ‚Ñπ 177 more rows
#> # ‚Ñπ 81 more variables: o3.daily.max.8hour <dbl>, o3.aot40v <int>,
#> #   o3.aot40f <int>, somo35 <dbl>, somo35.capture <dbl>, no <dbl>,
#> #   no.capture <dbl>, no2 <dbl>, no2.capture <dbl>, nox <dbl>,
#> #   nox.capture <dbl>, so2 <dbl>, so2.capture <dbl>, co <dbl>,
#> #   co.capture <dbl>, pm10 <dbl>, pm10.capture <dbl>, pm2.5 <dbl>,
#> #   pm2.5.capture <dbl>, gr10 <dbl>, gr10.capture <dbl>, gr2.5 <dbl>, ‚Ä¶
import_ukaq_summaries(year = 2024, source = "aurn", pivot = "long")
#> # A tibble: 8,228 √ó 8
#>    source date        year code  site                    pollutant  mean capture

#>  3 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 ABD9  Aberdeen Erroll Park    o3         56.0   0.878
#>  4 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 ACTH  Auchencorth Moss        o3         59.2   0.998
#>  5 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 AH    Aston Hill              o3         63.4   0.991
#>  6 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 ARM6  Armagh Roadside         o3         NA    NA    
#>  7 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 BAAR  Ballymena Antrim Road   o3         NA    NA

#> 10 aurn   2024-01-01  2024 BBRD  Birkenhead Borough Road o3         NA    NA    
#> # ‚Ñπ 8,218 more rows
import_ukaq_summaries("my1", 2020, data_type = "monthly", pivot = "long")

Daily Air Quality Index (DAQI)

Pre-calculated Daily Air Quality Indices (the ‚ÄòDAQI‚Äô, see https://uk-air.defra.gov.uk/air-pollution/daqi) are also available through import_ukaq_daqi(). This function is similar to import_ukaq_summaries(), with some additional nuances:

  1. The default pivot is "long". This is due to the amount of data presented - the daily statistic, the corresponding index, the corresponding band, and the measurement period. Not all of this information is carried to the ‚Äòwide‚Äô format if the alternative is selected.

  2. pollutant ensures only one of the five DAQI pollutants are given - any combination of NO2, O3, PM10, PM2.5 or SO2.

import_ukaq_daqi("my1", 2020)
#> # A tibble: 1,624 √ó 8
#>    source date       code  site     pollutant concentration poll_index poll_band
#>    <chr>  <date>     <chr> <chr>    <chr>             <dbl>      <int> <fct>    
#>  1 aurn   2020-01-01 MY1   London ‚Ä¶ no2               72.4           2 Low      
#>  2 aurn   2020-01-01 MY1   London ‚Ä¶ o3                 6             1 Low      
#>  3 aurn   2020-01-01 MY1   London ‚Ä¶ pm10              39             3 Low      
#>  4 aurn   2020-01-01 MY1   London ‚Ä¶ pm2.5             36             4 Moderate 
#>  5 aurn   2020-01-01 MY1   London ‚Ä¶ so2                9.15          1 Low      
#>  6 aurn   2020-01-02 MY1   London ‚Ä¶ no2               66.2           1 Low      
#>  7 aurn   2020-01-02 MY1   London ‚Ä¶ o3                25             1 Low      
#>  8 aurn   2020-01-02 MY1   London ‚Ä¶ pm10              15             1 Low      
#>  9 aurn   2020-01-02 MY1   London ‚Ä¶ pm2.5              9             1 Low      
#> 10 aurn   2020-01-02 MY1   London ‚Ä¶ so2                6.46          1 Low      
#> # ‚Ñπ 1,614 more rows
